comments.commentBody:
In Sports must have sportsmanship.

oxygen rental

The private high school where I work continues to headline football (no pun intended), has concussions every year, and pays huge money for liability insurance - which provides a pot of money ripe to be picked by litigation. The football program is also a large budget item. This is seen as normal.

On the other hand, I am not allowed to bring my 11 year old spaniel, a gentle pup who loves kids, to school for liability reasons. I don't know how you spell insanity, but this works for me.

This is just another money making scam for the lawyers.

30 years ago when I played grade school football, it was common knowledge that football injuries to the body and brain were possible at *any* level and may be permanent. Everyone playing football knows this and accepts it, even kids. I decided not to attempt college football because of this obvious, if perhaps small, risk.

Anyone who thinks playing sports is absolutely safe is deluding themselves and any attempt to get paid by legal scam later is just a fraud.

This should be thrown out of court and the plaintiff lawyer sanctioned.

Having hit my head hard twice in the last year, once by falling on a newly-waxed floor at work, and once by hitting myself on the head with my bike rack attached to my car trunk (forgot it was there: ouch!), I can say without question that second concussions are darn serious business. The first one left me groggy for a few hours. The second one, which was mild as these things go, left me lower-functioning for weeks, and with daily migraines for a month. And I knew about concussions, so I took some basic care of myself following the second one.

How did I know? My seven year-old son got one from falling on a concrete garage floor when he was wrestling with his sister. It made his first six weeks of school this year an absolute nightmare. He had the depression, the anxiety, the inability to concentrate. He lost friends, couldn't learn, snapped at people at home, didn't sleep well, and had visual migraines so disturbing that we had to take him to a pediatric opthamologist to be he wasn't suffering from some rare eye disorder. His new teacher asked us if he had been tested for ADHD, even after we'd told her he had a serious concussion. This is at a school with a "concussion plan" system in place! Supposedly, she should have understood how devastating this injury would be. But as a teacher myself, I can say that though I also had a kid on a concussion plan at the beginning of the year, few folks at my school have any real understanding of what this injury can do, including coaches.

If you haven't had a serious concussion(s), you can't imagine the damage it can do to your brain for weeks, months or years afterward. Some concussions are inevitable, but football courts them. The least they can do is heavily insure every single young athlete so that they are fully covered if they suffer from brain injury during play.

If you think this is just something a bunch of college boys need to get over, you have no idea how series even minor head injuries can be.

It's concerning that children could be removed from a home without a single criminal charge of abuse. If these parents were addicts we'd have heard about it in the amber alerts that were issued.

There are people speculating that the parents must have done something because the 11 month old was also removed. It is a practice of CPS to remove babies from mom at birth if older kids are in care. It's not uncommon for moms to hide pregnancies to prevent the seizure of newborns in hospital.

The system acts as a discount adoption service, babies and young children are in demand. Don't believe me? Go snoop on a foster parent chat forum.

What reason would CPS have for doing this? Money. The longer kids are in care the more money the social workers, agencies, therapists and foster parents make.

If I recall the US and its allies won in WW II and more or less in Korea. We lost politically in Vietnam due to the leftist press and will likely do so again in iraq and Afghanistan.

The unvarnished truth is that Bush invaded Iraq due to oil. Oil was and is the lifeblood of the industrialized West. Hussein was attacking and planning to attack other countries in order to capture the oil producing region so as to obtain the ability to acquire WMDs, which he once had and used. He then planned to attack both Israel and the US with nuclear weapons.

That Bush didn't explain this to and convince the American people of it was a serious mistake and possibly a violation of the Constitution. I tend to interpret the Constitution in a exegesist manner. Bush should have gotten a formal declaration of war from Congress.

But unlike Obama, at least he informed and got a feel good resolution from Congress. Obama declared war on Libya on his own without any consulting of Congress, an impeachable offense.

Americans and the Western World have to realize that the Middle East( including Muslims and Persians ) does not play by Robert's Rules of Order.

America never learned this in WWII, Korean War, Vietnam war with the Paris Peace Process, in Korea, in Iraq, and now in Afghanistan.

On the other hand, Eisenhower invaded South America for the American Fruit company, and Bush Jr. invaded Iraq on the "pretext" of WMD.

Countries follows their own rules when it suits them!

When a nation's embassy is attacked in such a way the international community recognizes it poses a threat to all nations' embassies. This simply is not acceptable behavior. Britain has every right to expel Iran's diplomats. I would like to see further alienation from the international community.

Countries always have ways of communicating with each other, either through intermediaries such as Switzerland or by invitation to meet at prearranged locations. The point here is to register extreme displeasure at Iran's illegal and ill-advised behavior. The lack of a serious response indicates weakness and a lack of resolve.

I would also add that Iran will get nukes if it really wants them, and there's nothing anyone can do about that. Not to worry though. Iran may not be smart about embassies, but it knows enough not to tangle with other nuclear-armed countries. Owning nukes is simply a strategic choice to gain a certain type of international respect.

I remember when Clinton took out the Chinese embassy in Belgrade with a precisely guided cruise missile.

The Chinese military suddenly realized that this technology was the wave of the future, and pulled the plug on billions of dollars of (now) obsolete military hardware, and re invested it into missiles, satellites, and guidance electronics.

So if you are wondering how the Chinese developed such a massive military presence; you can thank former President Clinton!

The Iranian régime's attack on the British embassy was worse than illegal under international law and immoral, it was stupid and damaging to Iran's national interest, but when the Iranian foreign ministry called Britain's retaliatory expulsion of Iran's mission from London " hasty " it had a good point. It is not smart to impair your ability to communicate with other countries, and especially not enemy countries. You never know when you will want to talk to the enemy; you may wish to do it in the middle of a battle. Communication is an option which should always be kept open. There must be other ways in which Britain could emphatically have expressed its displeasure at the Iranians' invasion of its embassy. And a demand for compensation would be a slam dunk under international law, as the severely embarrassed Iranian Foreign Ministry well knows.
Whose theocracy exactly?  That in the US by any chance?  :)

If the free world does not deal with this dangerous theocracy, the nuclear threat will become a real threat. It won't become any easier than it is today to halt their aggressiveness as time passes.

But at this time, we have so many problems to deal with at home, that this distraction away from home is easier left to sanctions and lesser efforts.

Gee, I thought I was the only one on the planet who didn't use Facebook or Twitter.

NYT - please expand this little comment box. It's hard to proofread and self-edit in this format.

I also think that the full comment should be seen instead of employing the 'read more' function.
Is that right? You have to have a facebook account to be trusted? That is insane. I feel like -not- having a facebook account would be grounds for trusting someone. Crazy.

Not a wise decision.A hasty step does not bring the desired result.
It will only complicate and compound the situation. Iran has diehard world wide supporters. It will also hasten development of more devastating weapons by Iran for fending off attacks by its enemies !!

why do you feel the need of censoring comments? wouldn't it be better to erase comments based on deliberation of readers's complaints? do you think the sensitivity of your comment editors superior to that of the public?
What a mess.

I agree, esp. with the irrelevance of the photo op. My photo currently looks way too old, and I'd prolly post one of my younger, hottier pix--diminishing the truth-in-posting ideal I otherwise hold to.

I'm with those who are seriously disappointed by the new comments system. The "Read More" feature is annoying; it will mean I read less and also comment less. I'm unhappy that a "class system" has been instituted for commenters, and even more that anyone not on Facebook is now a second-class commenter no matter how good their comments. I have zero use for photos of commenters; I'm interested in what they have to say, not what they look like. Finally, threading discourages one from coming back to see how a comment thread is developing, because you can't start reading from where the comments ended on your previous visit and catch all the new ones. Bad choices all around.
How long do I have to wait to find out if I'm a "trusted commenter"? I used to wait up to two days for a comment to even show up.
Thank you for this. Sounds very exciting. Times comments are very important to me.

I agree with pretty much all of what A.D. says.  Threads allow later commenters to attack each other.  The discussion degenerates.  To keep that from happening here will require close attention from staff.  I know, I'm using a thread, but in general I don't think they improve the quality of the comments.

Yours are the most insightful and cogent critiques so far. I especially like your point about commentators addressing the article, not each other. That simpler format prevented commentors from sounding like the Bickersons. Editor's picks were also a good index of different pov's.

AD, I am SO with you. The old Comments section mostly consisted of people writing about the article, not each other. And, while I am using this Reply feature now to agree with you, for the most part, these kinds of things degenerate into counterproductive flame wars, bringing down the overall tone of the site.

I agree, I will be much less likely to comment here in the future, and I had been asked to be a Trusted Commenter but would not because I would not link to Facebook.

These changes are God awful and are ruining my favorite news site. Might as well be Yahoo news. Terrible.

As an occasional commenter, I am disappointed in the changes, and as a result, for now, this is likely to be my last comment. A few parting thoughts:

1. What distinguished NYT comments from every other website (including major papers such as the Washington Post) was the fact that most comments addressed the article, not each other. Comments were often comprehensive, well thought out, and insightful. When comments did address each other, they did so at length and not in the casual conversational manner that is now inevitable. Many comments tended to be as good (and often better) than published Letters to the Editor.

2. In comment threads that climb into the hundreds, Editor's Picks provided an excellent way to skim the most insightful remarks, without wasting time reading through repetitive comments. It appears this feature has been replaced by "trusted" commenters -- a poor substitution. And linking to Facebook is simply silly: If a pseudonym has consistently provided respectful, interesting comments, why does the NYT need to link it to a "real" name? -- one imagines a certain historical author would have had to link to a "Samuel L. Clemens" account.

3. The "Read More" expansions are annoying and make skimming more difficult; moreover, the loading time is slow.

4. Putting newest comments first and threading comments are the two changes that have the potential to be beneficial.

Luckily, reporting -- not comments -- is why I read the NYT.
Hate it.  Comments used to be my favorite part of your articles.  Now, ugh.  How laborious and difficult it is to navigate your system to scan all of the comment content.
"can be shared" on Facebook? or we're forced to share?
Old system may not have been broken, but it wasan't the best going around. The fact that I can now comment directly on your comment is a great improvement.

What sounds like innovation to the comments section, i.e., giving some special status can verge dangerously close to censorship or favoritism toward  the type of elitist views that dominate NYT coverage.  Can the Times exhibit some self-awareness of its innate political and social prejudices?  And if being judgmental isn't bad enough, the tie-in with Facebook, the great bastion of privacy, is the cherry on this cake.

Sometimes change is not an improvement. The older system was clearer and more precise. My only complaint with the old system was that it took hours to get your comment up. Also this tiny little box that I am writing in makes it very difficult to see what I am typing and review it....we need a bigger box! Thanks.
You are wrong. Times highlights all sorts of comments.
Totally agree

I'm very disappointed that the Times is integrating with facebook on this level. It cheapens the paper. Nytimes felt like its own entity, separate from Facebook. Now it feels like an extension of this large network of vanity. I get home delivery, maybe this will be good grounds for avoiding the website entirely. It's crazy enough that paid subscribers still have to endure mercedes ads in the middle of a video. Nytimes is turning a better profit but is quickly losing its integrity. Congratulations.

This represents an injudicious use of the verb "to improve" ...if this were the Silicon Valley you would have launched a beta version and then digested / analyzed the comments before the abrupt change...one gets the sense that "change" is difficult for the Times...in fact there is no change process!
